title: Paris (City)
text: If you are lucky enough to have lived in Paris as a young man... it stays with you.
notes_internal: Copyrighted; keep short excerpt / consider paraphrase for commercial use

title: Paris (City)
text: Paris was originally a Roman settlement known as Lutetia.

title: Seine River (Central)
text: The Seine structures Paris culturally into Left Bank and Right Bank as well as geographically.

title: Eiffel Tower
text: Built for the 1889 Exposition Universelle, the Eiffel Tower was controversial at first.

title: Eiffel Tower (attributed line)
text: Paris is not a city; it’s a world.

title: Louvre Museum
text: The Louvre began as a medieval fortress before becoming a royal palace and then a museum.

title: Louvre Museum (art line)
text: Art is not what you see, but what you make others see.

title: Notre-Dame Cathedral
text: Great buildings are the work of centuries.

title: Notre-Dame Cathedral
text: Notre-Dame’s construction spanned roughly the 12th to 14th centuries.

title: Île de la Cité
text: Île de la Cité is among the historical cores of Paris’ earliest urban development.

title: Île Saint-Louis
text: Île Saint-Louis is known for its quiet streets and classic 17th-century atmosphere.

title: Sainte-Chapelle
text: Sainte-Chapelle is famous for its high stained-glass windows built for royal relics.

title: Conciergerie
text: The Conciergerie served as a prison during the French Revolution.

title: Pont Neuf
text: Despite its name, Pont Neuf is the oldest standing bridge across the Seine in Paris.

title: Pont des Arts
text: Pont des Arts became known for ‘love locks’ before they were removed for safety.

title: Pont Alexandre III
text: One of the most filmed bridges in Paris; a frequent establishing shot for ‘Paris-at-night’.

title: Musée d’Orsay
text: Housed in a former railway station, the Musée d’Orsay is a centerpiece for Impressionist art.

title: Musée de l’Orangerie
text: Home to Monet’s Water Lilies rooms—designed as immersive panoramic canvases.

title: Jardin des Tuileries
text: A classic open-air promenade linking the Louvre area to Place de la Concorde.

title: Place de la Concorde
text: A major Revolution-era site; the square’s history includes executions during the Terror.

title: Luxor Obelisk
text: An ancient Egyptian obelisk stands at the center of Place de la Concorde.

title: Champs-Élysées (Avenue)
text: Avenue connecting Concorde to Arc de Triomphe; iconic for parades and nighttime walks.

title: Arc de Triomphe
text: Under the Arc lies the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier with an eternal flame.

title: Place Charles de Gaulle (Étoile)
text: Twelve avenues radiate outward from the Arc’s roundabout—an urban starburst.

title: Grand Palais
text: Built for the 1900 Exposition Universelle; known for its glass barrel-vault roof.

title: Petit Palais
text: City of Paris museum with fine arts collections and a calm interior garden.

title: Invalides (Dôme)
text: Les Invalides houses Napoleon’s tomb beneath a prominent gilded dome.

title: Musée Rodin
text: Rodin’s sculpture garden is one of the most pleasant ‘slow museum’ experiences in Paris.

title: Latin Quarter (area)
text: Named for medieval academic Latin; still dense with students and book culture.

title: Sorbonne (area)
text: The historic University of Paris tradition shaped European scholarship for centuries.

title: Panthéon
text: A national mausoleum honoring major figures of French history and culture.

title: Panthéon (Marie Curie)
text: Marie Curie rests here; a scientific legacy anchored in the city’s civic memory.

title: Jardin du Luxembourg
text: A classic Paris park for chairs-by-the-fountain reading, chess, and slow afternoons.

title: Odéon (theatre area)
text: A natural ‘walk-and-talk’ zone often used in dialogue-driven Paris films.
notes_internal: Use as cinematic vibe card; add exact film references later

title: Shakespeare and Company
text: A landmark English-language bookshop associated with expatriate writers and literary Paris.

title: Shakespeare and Company (Before Sunset)
text: Appears in Before Sunset (2004) as a meeting-point in the opening sequence.

title: Saint-Étienne-du-Mont
text: Featured in Midnight in Paris (2011) as a late-night ‘time-slip’ starting point.

title: Place Dauphine
text: A quiet triangular square near Pont Neuf—often missed by first-time visitors.

title: Palais Royal Gardens
text: A classic filming backdrop: arcades, symmetry, and slow strolling energy.
notes_internal: Add concrete film references as you curate

title: Opéra Garnier
text: A landmark of Second Empire architecture and a frequent ‘Paris grandeur’ film setting.

title: Galeries Lafayette (Haussmann)
text: The glass dome makes this department store feel like a cathedral of commerce.

title: Place Vendôme
text: Designed as a symbol of royal power; now associated with luxury and jewelry houses.

title: Madeleine Church
text: A neoclassical church resembling a Roman temple at the edge of central Paris.

title: Place des Vosges
text: One of the oldest planned squares in Paris; a model of symmetry and calm.

title: Le Marais (district)
text: A dense historic district where medieval street patterns meet modern galleries and cafés.

title: Centre Pompidou
text: Inside-out architecture with exposed structure and color-coded systems; a modern Paris icon.

title: Place de la Bastille
text: Symbolic site of the French Revolution; the prison fortress once stood here.

title: Canal Saint-Martin
text: A popular Paris-cinema backdrop: water, iron footbridges, and long, slow conversations.
notes_internal: Add specific film references as you curate

title: Gare du Nord
text: Europe’s busiest rail hub by passenger numbers; an arrival scene in countless travel narratives.

title: Gare de Lyon
text: Known for the ornate clock tower and the historic Train Bleu restaurant inside the station.

title: Le Train Bleu (restaurant)
text: A Belle Époque restaurant inside Gare de Lyon—built for the 1900 exposition era.

title: Père Lachaise Cemetery
text: A major cultural cemetery with graves of artists and writers; a quiet ‘museum of memory’.

title: Père Lachaise (Oscar Wilde)
text: Oscar Wilde is buried here; the tomb became famous for devotion from visitors.

title: Belleville (district)
text: A hillside neighborhood with sweeping views and a distinctly local, less-touristed Paris feel.

title: Parc des Buttes-Chaumont
text: A dramatic park with cliffs, a lake, and a temple viewpoint—unexpected terrain for Paris.

title: Parc de la Villette
text: A modern cultural park blending architecture, museums, and open-air events.

title: Cité des Sciences et de l’Industrie
text: One of Europe’s largest science museums—good for ‘Paris beyond monuments’.
source_title: Cit%C3%A9 des Sciences et de l%27Industrie

title: Montparnasse Tower
text: A controversial skyline outlier; its observation deck gives a rare full-city panorama.

title: Catacombs Entrance
text: The Catacombs hold ossuary remains relocated from overcrowded cemeteries.

title: Pont de Bir-Hakeim
text: A visually distinctive bridge often used for stylized Paris sequences (arches, metro line, symmetry).

title: Trocadéro Gardens
text: A classic viewpoint framing the Eiffel Tower—one of the city’s most photographed compositions.

title: Champ de Mars
text: A large public green space aligned with the Eiffel Tower; a picnic-and-sunset magnet.

title: Place du Tertre
text: A small Montmartre square known for portrait artists and tourist bustle.

title: Café des Deux Moulins
text: Key recurring setting in Amélie (2001); fans visit for the film’s everyday Paris mood.

title: Place de l’Abbesse
text: A Montmartre cluster associated with Amélie-era Paris imagery and strolling routes.

title: Musée Picasso Paris
text: A major Picasso collection in the Marais; the building itself is part of the experience.

title: Place de la République
text: A major civic square often used for gatherings, demonstrations, and public memory.

title: Le Mur des Je t’aime
text: A wall featuring ‘I love you’ in many languages—modern romantic micro-pilgrimage.

title: Palais de Tokyo
text: A contemporary art center close to the Seine—often used for modern Paris culture routes.

title: Bois de Boulogne
text: A vast western park with lakes and paths—Paris’ ‘big nature’ escape zone.

title: Bois de Vincennes
text: A vast eastern park—good for routes that avoid the crowded center.

title: Parc Monceau
text: A refined park with classical follies and curved paths—very ‘19th-century stroll’.

title: Place Clichy
text: A lively junction between neighborhoods; useful node for cinema-and-streetlife themed walks.

title: Moulin Rouge
text: A famous cabaret; its imagery defines a certain ‘night Paris’ in popular culture.

title: Palace of Versailles
text: Versailles symbolizes French royal power; the Hall of Mirrors became a diplomatic stage.
notes_internal: Outside Paris proper; keep if you allow ‘Greater Paris’

title: Saint-Sulpice Church
text: Appears in The Da Vinci Code as part of the film’s Paris mystery trail.

title: Musée du Quai Branly
text: Museum focused on Indigenous and non-European arts; architecturally notable gardens.

title: Place Saint-Michel
text: A classic Left Bank meeting point near the Seine with dense foot traffic and street energy.

title: Rue Mouffetard
text: One of the oldest market streets in Paris; strong food-and-strolling atmosphere.

title: Marché d’Aligre
text: A lively market area combining covered and open-air stalls; local and chaotic in a good way.

title: Canal de l’Ourcq (Paris edge)
text: A canal route used for long walks and bike rides connecting to northeast Paris.

title: Bibliothèque François-Mitterrand
text: A modern national library complex; a different ‘Paris future’ vibe on the Seine.

title: Promenade Plantée (Coulée verte)
text: An elevated green walkway built on former railway infrastructure—quiet and surprisingly long.

title: Parc André Citroën
text: A modern park with broad lawns and greenhouse structures in southwest Paris.

title: La Défense (Grande Arche)
text: The modern business district’s Grande Arche extends Paris’ historic axis into the suburbs.
notes_internal: Outside Paris proper; include if you allow near-Paris

title: Place de la Nation
text: A large Paris square; useful as a civic and historical node for city-scale stories.

title: Parc de Bercy
text: A park built on old wine warehouses—Bercy’s identity is literally fermented history.

title: Accor Arena (Bercy)
text: Major concert venue—good anchor for music/nightlife-themed layers.

title: Place du Châtelet
text: A classic central node for ‘Paris at speed’ sequences: bridges, theatres, and river proximity.

title: Hôtel de Ville
text: Paris’ city hall anchors civic identity; the square often hosts public installations and events.

title: Place des Abbesses (Metro)
text: One of the deepest metro stations; an ‘underworld-to-hillside’ Paris experience.

title: Le Bon Marché
text: Often called the first modern department store—Paris helped invent retail theater.

title: Passage des Panoramas
text: One of Paris’ covered passages—glass-roof arcades built for strolling and window-shopping.

title: Passage Jouffroy
text: A nearby covered passage with antique shops and a slow-time feel in the 9th arrondissement.

title: Maison de Victor Hugo
text: Victor Hugo lived here (Place des Vosges); a direct literary anchor in the Marais.

title: Le Père Tanguy (art myth)
text: Montmartre and nearby streets are tied to the mythology of modern art communities and ateliers.
notes_internal: Use as ‘art mythos’ layer; add precise references later

title: La Petite Ceinture (segment)
text: A former railway ring around Paris; some sections are now reclaimed as urban nature walks.

title: Butte-aux-Cailles
text: A small hilltop neighborhood known for village-like streets and street art.

title: Place Denfert-Rochereau
text: A major south-Paris junction; gateway to the Catacombs and the city’s underground narratives.

title: Before Sunset (Seine walk vibe)
text: Before Sunset (2004) is essentially a Paris walk; the city becomes the third character through movement.
notes_internal: No dialogue used; tie to specific filming spots later
